reasoning: The critique targets a largely omitted assumption: that accelerating AI R&D is mainly constrained by idea-generation + experiment-running (compute), whereas verification/evaluation/auditing could become the dominant bottleneck and thus throttle the pace of software progress even if compute isn’t limiting. This is moderately central because it undercuts the practical upshot (“compute bottlenecks likely won’t stop early SIE”), but it doesn’t directly refute the narrower claim about compute-bottleneck strength itself—compute could indeed not bind while verification binds. The argument is conceptually plausible but mostly asserted rather than demonstrated (no modeling, empirical trend evidence, or linkage to the CES framing), so it only partially weakens the position. Many claims are speculative/futures-focused but not obviously false. The critique is clear, focused on one mechanism, and contains little dead weight.
title: The paper underestimates verification costs that become the dominant AI progress bottleneck
